questions.question_text: When you configure and apply an IOA exclusion, what impact does it have on the host and what you see in the console?

choices.D: The associated IOA will still generate a detection but the associated process would have been allowed to run
choices.C: The sensor will stop sending events from the process specified in the regex pattern
choices.B: The associated detection will be suppressed and the associated process would have been allowed to run
choices.A: The process specified is not sent to the Falcon Sandbox for analysis

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the answer. It is found in the Doc under " Understand Exclusions" " By creating an exclusion you stop seeing detections that you don't want to see, and allow processes that would otherwise be prevented.

Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B, Allow

Checked the IOC management UI, the "action" only have four types : Block, Detect Only, Allow and Block + hide detection.

Selected Answer: B
The option that indicates a hash is allowlisted is:

B. Allow

When a hash is allowlisted, it means that it is explicitly permitted and allowed to run or perform its intended actions on the system. Therefore, selecting "Allow" indicates that the hash is included in the allowlist.

Selected Answer: B
Use allow to add hash to allowlist. IoC Management only supports allowlisting in Hash. To apply for IP and Domains, use IoA Rules.

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. No Action, Never block, Always Block, and Remove Hashes are the only options.

comments.content: wrong you did not check at all bc no where in the UI is an "allow" an option
This time he's right lol. There is 'allow' in IoC Hash

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
checked in docs

questions.question_text: Which option indicates a hash is allowlisted?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Event workflows are automated searches that can be used to pivot between related events and searches. To use a workflow, click the Event Actions button at the bottom of the JSON for any raw event

Selected Answer: A
This is A

the other sources also say B but the CrowdStrike pdfs list event actions as pivot from an Event Search so this goes more with A. they are hyperlinks to automated searches so not sure but i am choosing A until otherwise i get new info
Appears to be A as Event actions aren't necessarily only available in host search

choices.B: Pivotable hyperlinks available in a Host Search
choices.A: Automated searches that can be used to pivot between related events and searches
choices.C: Custom event data queries bookmarked by the currently signed in Falcon user

questions.question_text: How long does detection data remain in the CrowdStrike Cloud before purging begins?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct. 90 days from cloud. 30 days on host
